comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The Royal Hanneford Circus is an American-based touring family circus. With origins dating back to 1690, it has been called the oldest circus in the world.[1] The family first performed as a traveling troupe in 1807. In 1903, the family began its own circus as the "Hanneford Royal Canadian Circus" and in their early seasons toured the British Isles and Continental Europe en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Hanneford_Circus

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
The Circus was well established - there are pics of them in Strabane in the late 1800's and had their own productions on the go by 1903 and they are still on the go today.

They get the title Royal from having performed for King George III in 1778.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The Penny Illustrated Paper and Illustrated Times, Saturday, June 17, 1905:
PANIC IN AN IRISH CIRCUS The escape of a lioness caused great excitement at a performance in Queenstown, last week, of Hanneford's Circus. The circus was crowded to its fullest extent when one of the keepers, in full view of the audience, opened the door of the animal's cage preparatory to entering. With a sudden bound the lioness leaped through the door and escaped, amid the cries and shrieks of terrified spectators, the majority of whom were children. The beast jumped into the middle of the ring and knocked down a boy named White, tearing most of the skin from his face with her claws. Then she attacked another boy, and wrenched off part of his jacket. The lioness, pursued by the keepers, made another dash, and succeeded in getting out of the enclosure into an adjoining field, where she lay down. Eventually she was lassoed, numerous attendants and a large dog assisting in the capture.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
I still have high hopes for 1907 as a date for this one! An ad in the Ulster Herald on Saturday, 23 June 1906 advertises them as visiting Enniskillen, Irvinestown, Dromore, Fintona, Omagh and Newtownstewart with 10 clowns or a "Cartload of Clowns" as it says further down. By June of 1907, an ad in the Nenagh News trumpets 16 Clowns! 16 Clowns! No mention of Clown Inflation figures by April 1909, but the Nenagh News advertises:
... Mons. Permane and his Talking Bear and the Bear that Rides on Horseback. The Latest Zoological Wonder - the Live Teddy Bears! ... 120 Horses, Ponies, Mules, Donkeys, Dogs, Elephants, Camels, Lions, Bears, Wolves, Kangaroos, Sheep, Birds, Monkeys, &c. ...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
